title: Mahogany
summary: Mahogany is a straight-grained, reddish-brown timber of three tropical hardwood species of the genus Swietenia, indigenous to the Americas[1] and part of the pantropical chinaberry family, Meliaceae. Mahogany is used commercially for a wide variety of goods, due to its coloring and durable nature. It is naturally found within the Americas, however have also been imported to plantations across Asia and Oceania. Mahogany trade may have begun as early as the 16th Century and flourished with the 17th and 18th Centuries. In certain countries, mahogany is considered an invasive species.
